message_text: Paper Title: Colloquium: Quantum and classical discrete time crystals Paper Abstract: The spontaneous breaking of time translation symmetry has led to the discovery of a new phase of matter - the discrete time crystal. Discrete time crystals exhibit rigid subharmonic oscillations, which result from a combination of many-body interactions, collective synchronization, and ergodicity breaking. This Colloquium reviews recent theoretical and experimental advances in the study of quantum and classical discrete time crystals. We focus on the breaking of ergodicity as the key to discrete time crystals and the delaying of ergodicity as the source of numerous phenomena that share many of the properties of discrete time crystals, including the AC Josephson effect, coupled map lattices, and Faraday waves. Theoretically, there exists a diverse array of strategies to stabilize time crystalline order in both closed and open systems, ranging from localization and prethermalization to dissipation and error correction. Experimentally, many-body quantum simulators provide a natural platform for investigating signatures of time crystalline order; recent work utilizing trapped ions, solid-state spin systems, and superconducting qubits will be reviewed. Finally, this Colloquium concludes by describing outstanding challenges in the field and a vision for new directions on both the experimental and theoretical fronts. "contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.) "survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work) task - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding) method - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction) data - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus) artifact - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9) tool - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope) concept - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory) other - Entities that don't fit above categories uses - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks) proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS: - ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work) - CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new) { "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey", "triples": [ { "name": "Wikipedia Article Title", "relation": "uses|proposes", "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other", "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...", "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)" } ] } FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool: CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do. 1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field. 2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation. 3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia. 4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm") - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes) - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/) - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters 5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py 6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes. When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter: WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"]) This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains. Begin now.

Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about discrete time crystals:

## What is a Discrete Time Crystal?

A discrete time crystal is a system in which discrete time-translation symmetry is broken, which may be realized in periodically driven systems.

## Key Characteristics

A discrete time crystal never reaches thermal equilibrium, as it is a type (or phase) of non-equilibrium matter.(no content)Breaking of time symmetry can occur only in non-equilibrium systems.(no content)The time crystals that are experimentally realized show discrete time-translation symmetry breaking, not the continuous one: they are periodically driven systems oscillating at a fraction of the frequency of the driving force.

## Historical Background

Time crystals were first proposed theoretically by Alfred Shapere and Frank Wilczek in 2012 as a time-based analogue to common crystals – whereas the atoms in crystals are arranged periodically in space, the atoms in a time crystal are arranged periodically in both space and time.(no content)Discrete time crystals have in fact been observed in physics laboratories as early as 2016.

## Practical Applications

In terms of practical use, time crystals may one day be used as quantum computer memory.

I've completed a web search for "quantum simulator." Here are the key findings:

## What is a Quantum Simulator?

Quantum simulators permit the study of a quantum system in a programmable fashion.(no content)They are special purpose devices designed to provide insight about specific physics problems.

## Why Quantum Simulators Matter

Conventional computers, including supercomputers, are inadequate for simulating quantum systems with as few as 30 particles because the dimension of the Hilbert space grows exponentially with particle number.(no content)Quantum simulators can solve problems which are difficult to simulate on classical computers because they directly exploit quantum properties of real particles.

## Experimental Implementations

Quantum simulators have been realized on a number of experimental platforms, including systems of ultracold quantum gases, polar molecules, trapped ions, photonic systems, quantum dots, and superconducting circuits.

## Recent Applications

Recently quantum simulators have been used to obtain time crystals and quantum spin liquids.

## Software Tools

Several software frameworks are available for quantum simulation:
- QuTiP, short for the Quantum Toolbox in Python, is an open-source computational physics software library for simulating quantum systems, particularly open quantum systems.
- Cirq is an open-source framework for noisy intermediate scale quantum (NISQ) computers.

I've completed a web search for "quantum simulator." Here are the key findings:

## What is a Quantum Simulator?

Quantum simulators permit the study of a quantum system in a programmable fashion.(no content)They are special purpose devices designed to provide insight about specific physics problems.

## Why Quantum Simulators Matter

Conventional computers, including supercomputers, are inadequate for simulating quantum systems with as few as 30 particles because the dimension of the Hilbert space grows exponentially with particle number.(no content)Quantum simulators can solve problems which are difficult to simulate on classical computers because they directly exploit quantum properties of real particles.

## Experimental Implementations

Quantum simulators have been realized on a number of experimental platforms, including systems of ultracold quantum gases, polar molecules, trapped ions, photonic systems, quantum dots, and superconducting circuits.

## Recent Applications

Recently quantum simulators have been used to obtain time crystals and quantum spin liquids.

## Software Tools

Several software frameworks are available for quantum simulation:
- QuTiP, short for the Quantum Toolbox in Python, is an open-source computational physics software library for simulating quantum systems, particularly open quantum systems.
- Cirq is an open-source framework for noisy intermediate scale quantum (NISQ) computers.

Web search results for query: "time translation symmetry"

Links: [{"title":"Time-translation symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-translation_symmetry"},{"title":"Time crystal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_crystal"},{"title":"Spacetime symmetries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spacetime_symmetries"},{"title":"Symmetry (physics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_in_physics"},{"title":"Conservation of energy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_of_energy"},{"title":"T-symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T-symmetry"},{"title":"Translational symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Translational_symmetry"},{"title":"Time symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_symmetry"},{"title":"Noether's theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noether's_theorem"},{"title":"Symmetry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry_transformation"}]

## Time Translation Symmetry

Time-translation symmetry or temporal translation symmetry (TTS) is a mathematical transformation in physics that moves the times of events through a common interval.(no content)Time-translation symmetry is the law that the laws of physics are unchanged (i.e. invariant) under such a transformation.

### Mathematical Description

A physical system may have the same features over a certain interval of time Δt; this is expressed mathematically as invariance under the transformation t → t + a for any real parameters t and t + a in the interval.

### Connection to Energy Conservation

One of the most important implications of time-translation symmetry is its relationship to energy conservation. Temporal translation symmetry (i.e. homogeneity of time) gives rise to conservation of energy.(no content)The energy conservation law is a consequence of the shift symmetry of time; energy conservation is implied by the empirical fact that the laws of physics do not change with time itself. Philosophically this can be stated as "nothing depends on time per se".

### Role of Noether's Theorem

Symmetries in nature lead directly to conservation laws, something which is precisely formulated by Noether's theorem.(no content)Noether's theorem states that every continuous symmetry of the action of a physical system with conservative forces has a corresponding conservation law. This is the first of two theorems published by the mathematician Emmy Noether in 1918.

### Breaking Time-Translation Symmetry

Interestingly, time crystals, a state of matter first observed in 2017, break time-translation symmetry.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "ergodicity breaking"

Links: [{"title":"Ergodic hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_hypothesis"},{"title":"Ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity"},{"title":"Ergodic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_process"},{"title":"Ergodicity economics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodicity_economics"},{"title":"Ergodic theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ergodic_theory"},{"title":"Quantum ergodicity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_ergodicity"},{"title":"Stationary ergodic process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stationary_ergodic_process"},{"title":"Quantum scar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_scar"},{"title":"Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigenstate_thermalization_hypothesis"},{"title":"Talk:Ergodic hypothesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Ergodic_hypothesis"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of ergodicity breaking:

## Definition and Basic Concept

In macroscopic systems, the timescales over which a system can truly explore the entirety of its own phase space can be sufficiently large that the thermodynamic equilibrium state exhibits some form of ergodicity breaking. To understand this, it's helpful to know that ergodicity expresses the idea that a point of a moving system will eventually visit all parts of the space in which the system moves, in a uniform and random sense, which implies that the average behavior of the system can be deduced from the trajectory of a "typical" point.

## Key Examples

A common example is that of spontaneous magnetisation in ferromagnetic systems, whereby below the Curie temperature the system preferentially adopts a non-zero magnetisation even though the ergodic hypothesis would imply that no net magnetisation should exist by virtue of the system exploring all states whose time-averaged magnetisation should be zero.(no content)The fact that macroscopic systems often violate the literal form of the ergodic hypothesis is an example of spontaneous symmetry breaking.(no content)Complex disordered systems such as a spin glass show an even more complicated form of ergodicity breaking where the properties of the thermodynamic equilibrium state seen in practice are much more difficult to predict purely by symmetry arguments.

## Quantum Systems

In quantum mechanics, classical ergodic behavior can break down, as exemplified by the presence of quantum scars.(no content)There are two other types of quantum scarring, which further illustrate the weak-ergodicity breaking in quantum chaotic systems: perturbation-induced and many-body quantum scars.

## Applications

Non-ergodicity is closely related to the problems of irreversibility and path dependence that are common themes in economics.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "trapped ions quantum computing"

Links: [{"title":"Trapped-ion quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trapped-ion_quantum_computer"},{"title":"IonQ - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IonQ"},{"title":"David J. Wineland - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_J._Wineland"},{"title":"Ion trap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion_trap"},{"title":"Mølmer–Sørensen gate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mølmer–Sørensen_gate"},{"title":"Isaac Chuang - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isaac_Chuang"},{"title":"Cirac–Zoller controlled-NOT gate","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cirac–Zoller_controlled-NOT_gate"},{"title":"Talk:Trapped ion quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Trapped_ion_quantum_computer"},{"title":"Institute for Quantum Optics and Quantum Information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_for_Quantum_Optics_and_Quantum_Information"},{"title":"Penning trap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penning_trap"}]

The search returned comprehensive information about trapped ions quantum computing. Here's what I found:

## Overview

A trapped-ion quantum computer (TIQC) is one proposed approach to a large-scale quantum computer.(no content)Ions, or charged atomic particles, can be confined and suspended in free space using electromagnetic fields.

## How It Works

Qubits are stored in stable electronic states of each ion, and quantum information can be transferred through the collective quantized motion of the ions in a shared trap (interacting through the Coulomb force).(no content)Lasers are applied to induce coupling between the qubit states (for single qubit operations) or coupling between the internal qubit states and the external motional states (for entanglement between qubits).

## Advantages and Progress

The fundamental operations of a quantum computer have been demonstrated experimentally with the currently highest accuracy in trapped-ion systems.(no content)This makes the trapped-ion quantum computer system one of the most promising architectures for a scalable, universal quantum computer.(no content)As of December 2023, the largest number of particles to be controllably entangled is 32 trapped ions.

## Historical Development

The first implementation scheme for a controlled-NOT quantum gate was proposed by Ignacio Cirac and Peter Zoller in 1995, specifically for the trapped-ion system. The same year, a key step in the controlled-NOT gate was experimentally realized at NIST Ion Storage Group.

## Challenges

The main challenges facing trapped-ion quantum computing are the initialization of the ion's motional states, and the relatively brief lifetimes of the phonon states. Decoherence also proves to be challenging to eliminate, and is caused when the qubits interact with the external environment undesirably.

The search returned comprehensive information about trapped ions quantum computing. Here's what I found:

## Overview

A trapped-ion quantum computer (TIQC) is one proposed approach to a large-scale quantum computer.(no content)Ions, or charged atomic particles, can be confined and suspended in free space using electromagnetic fields.

## How It Works

Qubits are stored in stable electronic states of each ion, and quantum information can be transferred through the collective quantized motion of the ions in a shared trap (interacting through the Coulomb force).(no content)Lasers are applied to induce coupling between the qubit states (for single qubit operations) or coupling between the internal qubit states and the external motional states (for entanglement between qubits).

## Advantages and Progress

The fundamental operations of a quantum computer have been demonstrated experimentally with the currently highest accuracy in trapped-ion systems.(no content)This makes the trapped-ion quantum computer system one of the most promising architectures for a scalable, universal quantum computer.(no content)As of December 2023, the largest number of particles to be controllably entangled is 32 trapped ions.

## Historical Development

The first implementation scheme for a controlled-NOT quantum gate was proposed by Ignacio Cirac and Peter Zoller in 1995, specifically for the trapped-ion system. The same year, a key step in the controlled-NOT gate was experimentally realized at NIST Ion Storage Group.

## Challenges

The main challenges facing trapped-ion quantum computing are the initialization of the ion's motional states, and the relatively brief lifetimes of the phonon states. Decoherence also proves to be challenging to eliminate, and is caused when the qubits interact with the external environment undesirably.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about coupled map lattices:

## Definition and Purpose

A coupled map lattice (CML) is a dynamical system that models the behavior of nonlinear systems (especially partial differential equations).(no content)They are predominantly used to qualitatively study the chaotic dynamics of spatially extended systems.

## How They Work

The CML system evolves through discrete time by a mapping on vector sequences, with these mappings being a recursive function of two competing terms: an individual non-linear reaction, and a spatial interaction (coupling) of variable intensity.

## Classification by Coupling Strength

CMLs can be classified by the strength of this coupling parameter(s). The main categories include:

- **Weak coupling:** Weak coupling with monotonic (bistable) dynamical regimes demonstrate spatial chaos phenomena and are popular in neural models.
- **Strong coupling:** Strong coupling interactions are most well known to model synchronization effects of dynamic spatial systems such as the Kuramoto model.

## Notable Properties

Surprisingly the dynamics of CMLs have little to do with the local maps that constitute their elementary components. This makes them a valuable tool for understanding complex spatiotemporal phenomena in nonlinear systems.

Links: [{"title":"Faraday wave - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_wave"},{"title":"Faraday effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Faraday_effect"},{"title":"Standing wave - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standing_wave"},{"title":"Maxwell's equations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maxwell's_equations"},{"title":"Michael Faraday - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Faraday"},{"title":"History of electromagnetic theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_electromagnetic_theory"},{"title":"James Clerk Maxwell - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Clerk_Maxwell"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about Faraday waves:

## Definition and Basics

Faraday waves, also known as Faraday ripples, named after Michael Faraday (1791–1867), are nonlinear standing waves that appear on liquids enclosed by a vibrating receptacle.(no content)When the vibration frequency exceeds a critical value, the flat hydrostatic surface becomes unstable.

## Applications and Uses

Faraday waves have several interesting applications:

- Faraday waves are used as a liquid-based template for directed assembly of microscale materials including soft matter, rigid bodies, biological entities (e.g., individual cells, cell spheroids and cell-seeded microcarrier beads).

- This effect can also be used for mixing two liquids acoustically. Faraday waves form on the interface between the two liquids, which increases the surface area between the two, rapidly and thoroughly mixing the liquids.

## Natural Occurrence

This phenomenon is also used by alligators to call mates. They vibrate their lungs at low frequencies slightly below the surface, causing their spikes to move and induce surface waves. These surface waves are basically Faraday waves and one can observe the splashing effect characteristic of certain resonances.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "AC Josephson effect"

Links: [{"title":"Josephson effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_effect"},{"title":"Josephson diode - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_diode"},{"title":"Josephson voltage standard - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_voltage_standard"},{"title":"Talk:Josephson effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Josephson_effect"},{"title":"Category:Josephson effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Josephson_effect"},{"title":"Magnetic flux quantum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_constant"},{"title":"Brian Josephson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Josephson"},{"title":"Pi Josephson junction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pi_Josephson_junction"},{"title":"Phi Josephson junction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phi_Josephson_junction"},{"title":"Josephson junction count - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Josephson_junction_count"}]

## AC Josephson Effect

The Josephson effect is a phenomenon that occurs when two superconductors are placed in proximity, with some barrier or restriction between them, named after the British physicist Brian Josephson, who predicted in 1962 the mathematical relationships for the current and voltage across the weak link.(no content)Josephson discovered that a supercurrent could tunnel through a thin barrier, predicting that "at a junction of two superconductors, a current will flow even if there is no drop in voltage; that when there is a voltage drop, the current should oscillate at a frequency related to the drop in voltage; and that there is a dependence on any magnetic field." This oscillating current behavior when voltage is applied is the AC Josephson effect.

The Josephson effect produces a current, known as a supercurrent, that flows continuously without any voltage applied, across a device known as a Josephson junction (JJ). This consists of two or more superconductors coupled by a weak link.(no content)The Josephson effect has many practical applications because it exhibits a precise relationship between different physical measures, such as voltage and frequency, facilitating highly accurate measurements.(no content)Josephson junctions have important applications in quantum-mechanical circuits, such as SQUIDs, superconducting qubits, and RSFQ digital electronics.

Links: [{"title":"Anderson localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anderson_localization"},{"title":"Talk:Anderson localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Anderson_localization"},{"title":"Weak localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weak_localization"},{"title":"Anderson model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anderson_model"},{"title":"Brian Anderson (electrical engineer) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brian_Anderson_(academic)"},{"title":"Localization-protected quantum order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Localization_protected_quantum_order"},{"title":"Alain Aspect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Aspect"},{"title":"John Ballato - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Ballato"},{"title":"Ace Attorney - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ace_Attorney"}]

Here are the search results for Anderson localization:

## Overview

In condensed matter physics, Anderson localization (also known as strong localization) is the absence of diffusion of waves in a disordered medium.(no content)This phenomenon is named after the American physicist P. W. Anderson, who was the first to suggest that electron localization is possible in a lattice potential, provided that the degree of randomness (disorder) in the lattice is sufficiently large, as can be realized for example in a semiconductor with impurities or defects.

## Generality of the Phenomenon

Anderson localization is a general wave phenomenon that applies to the transport of electromagnetic waves, acoustic waves, quantum waves, spin waves, etc.

## Related Concepts

This phenomenon is to be distinguished from weak localization, which is the precursor effect of Anderson localization, and from Mott localization, named after Sir Nevill Mott, where the transition from metallic to insulating behaviour is not due to disorder, but to a strong mutual Coulomb repulsion of electrons.

## Physical Mechanism

The phenomenon of Anderson localization, particularly that of weak localization, finds its origin in the wave interference between multiple-scattering paths. In the strong scattering limit, the severe interferences can completely halt the waves inside the disordered medium.

## Experimental Demonstrations

Alain Aspect was the first to demonstrate Anderson localization in an ultra-cold atom system.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "superconducting qubit"

Links: [{"title":"Superconducting quantum computing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superconducting_quantum_computing"},{"title":"Transmon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transmon"},{"title":"Phase qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase_qubit"},{"title":"Charge qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charge_qubit"},{"title":"Flux qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flux_qubit"},{"title":"Yasunobu Nakamura - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yasunobu_Nakamura"},{"title":"File:Superconducting qubits electrical diagrams.pdf - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Superconducting_qubits_electrical_diagrams.pdf"},{"title":"Circuit quantum electrodynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circuit_quantum_electrodynamics"},{"title":"Qubit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Qubit"},{"title":"Cat qubit quantum computer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cat_qubit_quantum_computer"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about superconducting qubits:

## Overview

A qubit is a basic unit of quantum information and a two-state quantum-mechanical system. Superconducting qubits are a physical implementation of these quantum bits using superconducting circuits.

## Design and Construction

Superconductors are implemented at low temperatures where they have infinite conductivity and zero resistance, with each qubit built using semiconductor circuits containing a capacitor and an inductor that produce a resonant circuit dissipating almost no energy.

A distinguishable attribute of superconducting quantum circuits is the use of Josephson junctions, which are superconducting elements with nonlinear inductance that produces uneven spacing between energy levels.

Superconducting quantum computing devices are typically designed in the radio-frequency spectrum, cooled in dilution refrigerators below 15 mK, with typical dimensions falling in the micrometer range.

## Main Types of Superconducting Qubits

Several important architectures include:

1. **Charge Qubits**: In superconducting quantum computing, a charge qubit is formed by a tiny superconducting island coupled by a Josephson junction to a superconducting reservoir.

2. **Flux Qubits**: Flux qubits are micrometer sized loops of superconducting metal interrupted by a number of Josephson junctions that function as quantum bits.

3. **Transmon Qubits**: A transmon is a type of superconducting charge qubit designed to have reduced sensitivity to charge noise, developed at Yale University and Université de Sherbrooke in 2007.

## Advantages

Superconductors have the advantage of being more easily scaled and are more coherent than normal solid-state systems.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed the web search for "quantum error correction." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Quantum error correction (QEC) comprises a set of techniques used in quantum memory and quantum computing to protect quantum information from errors arising from decoherence and other sources of quantum noise.

## Key Concepts

**Error Types and Detection:** In most QECCs, the type of error is either a bit flip, or a phase flip, or both.(no content)The stabilizers to be measured are carefully chosen so as not to reveal any logical information, but only information about the errors themselves.

**Threshold Theorem:** The quantum threshold theorem shows that quantum computations of arbitrary length are possible. It states that errors can be corrected by recursively concatenating quantum codes—such as CSS codes—across logarithmically many levels, provided the error rate of individual quantum gates remains below a certain threshold.

## Recent Developments

Surface codes are pivotal for scalable quantum error correction in 2025, enabling below-threshold logical qubits with improved fidelity in superconducting systems.(no content)In 2016 for the first time the lifetime of a quantum bit was prolonged by employing a QEC code. The error-correction demonstration was performed on Schrödinger-cat states encoded in a superconducting resonator. The work demonstrated how the quantum-error-corrected system reaches the break-even point at which the lifetime of a logical qubit exceeds the lifetime of the underlying constituents of the system.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed the web search for "quantum error correction." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Quantum error correction (QEC) comprises a set of techniques used in quantum memory and quantum computing to protect quantum information from errors arising from decoherence and other sources of quantum noise.

## Key Concepts

**Error Types and Detection:** In most QECCs, the type of error is either a bit flip, or a phase flip, or both.(no content)The stabilizers to be measured are carefully chosen so as not to reveal any logical information, but only information about the errors themselves.

**Threshold Theorem:** The quantum threshold theorem shows that quantum computations of arbitrary length are possible. It states that errors can be corrected by recursively concatenating quantum codes—such as CSS codes—across logarithmically many levels, provided the error rate of individual quantum gates remains below a certain threshold.

## Recent Developments

Surface codes are pivotal for scalable quantum error correction in 2025, enabling below-threshold logical qubits with improved fidelity in superconducting systems.(no content)In 2016 for the first time the lifetime of a quantum bit was prolonged by employing a QEC code. The error-correction demonstration was performed on Schrödinger-cat states encoded in a superconducting resonator. The work demonstrated how the quantum-error-corrected system reaches the break-even point at which the lifetime of a logical qubit exceeds the lifetime of the underlying constituents of the system.

Links: [{"title":"Many-body problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Many-body_problem"},{"title":"n-body problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N-body_problem"},{"title":"Interatomic potential - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interatomic_potential"},{"title":"Three-body problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-body_problem"},{"title":"Three-body force - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three-body_force"},{"title":"N-body simulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N-body_simulation"},{"title":"Interaction energy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interaction_energy"},{"title":"Two-body problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-body_problem"},{"title":"Multibody system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multibody_system"},{"title":"Many-body localization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Many-body_localization"}]

Based on the web search results, here's a comprehensive overview of many-body interaction physics:

## Overview

The quantum many-body problem is a general name for a vast category of physical problems pertaining to deriving the behavior of multi-particle systems using fundamental quantum-mechanical principles. The goal of many-body physics is to find new principles to describe macroscopic systems, using principles that pertain to microscopic systems.

## Core Challenges

When the amount of particles in a system increases, repulsive interactions between electrons occur, and the term in Schrödinger's equation that corresponds to the energy of these repulsions is impossible to solve for.(no content)In quantum mechanics, the dimension of the many-body wave function scales exponentially with the number of particles. Because the required numerical expense grows so quickly, simulating the dynamics of more than three quantum-mechanical particles is already infeasible for many physical systems.

## Three-Body and Higher Interactions

A three-body force is a force that does not exist in a system of two objects but appears in a three-body system. In general, if the behaviour of a system of more than two objects cannot be described by the two-body interactions between all possible pairs, as a first approximation, the deviation is mainly due to a three-body force.

## Practical Applications

Quantitative molecular dynamics simulations are carried out with various of many-body potentials. Additionally, many-body localization (MBL) is a dynamical phenomenon occurring in isolated many-body quantum systems. It is characterized by the system failing to reach thermal equilibrium, and retaining a memory of its initial condition in local observables for infinite times.

I've completed the web search for "solid-state spin system quantum". Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview of Solid-State Spin Systems

The search results reveal several important aspects of quantum spin systems in solid-state materials:

**Spin Basics in Quantum Systems:**
Unlike classical wavefield circulation, which allows continuous values of angular momentum, quantum wavefields allow only discrete values, and consequently, energy transfer to or from spin states always occurs in fixed quantum steps.

**Spin Models:**
A quantum spin model is a quantum Hamiltonian model that describes a system which consists of spins either interacting or not and are an active area of research in the fields of strongly correlated electron systems, quantum information theory, and quantum computing.(no content)For instance, the Ising model describes spins (dipoles) that have only two possible states, up and down, whereas in the Heisenberg model the spin vector is allowed to point in any direction.

**Spintronics Applications:**
Spintronics, also known as spin electronics, is the study of the intrinsic spin of the electron and its associated magnetic moment, in addition to its fundamental electronic charge, in solid-state devices.

**Quantum Computing Applications:**
Nuclear magnetic resonance quantum computing (NMRQC) is one of the several proposed approaches for constructing a quantum computer, that uses the spin states of nuclei within molecules as qubits, and solid state NMR (SSNMR) has superseded liquid state NMR as a means of quantum computation.

**Advanced Techniques:**
Solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (ssNMR) is a spectroscopy technique used to characterize atomic-level structure and dynamics in solid materials.

Based on the search results, I found information related to thermalization in quantum systems, though the results don't explicitly focus on "prethermalization" as a specific term. Here's what the search reveals about related concepts:

## Thermalization in Quantum Systems

The eigenstate thermalization hypothesis (ETH) is a set of ideas which purports to explain when and why an isolated quantum mechanical system can be accurately described using equilibrium statistical mechanics, in particular, it is devoted to understanding how systems which are initially prepared in far-from-equilibrium states can evolve in time to a state which appears to be in thermal equilibrium.(no content)Experiments in cold atomic gases have indeed observed thermal relaxation in systems which are, to a very good approximation, completely isolated from their environment, and for a wide class of initial states.

## Exceptions to Thermalization

Notably, not all quantum systems undergo thermalization. Not all quantum states undergo thermalisation, and some states have been discovered which do not reach thermal equilibrium.(no content)Many-body integrable systems, which have an extensive number of conserved quantities, will not thermalise in the usual sense, but will equilibrate according to a generalized Gibbs ensemble.

The search results provide context about quantum thermalization processes, but to get more specific information about the prethermalization phenomenon (which typically refers to the intermediate dynamical stages before full thermalization occurs), you may want to search for more specialized physics literature or research papers on this topic.

## Thermalization in Quantum Systems

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Survey

This Colloquium paper is a comprehensive review of discrete time crystals rather than proposing entirely new work. It reviews recent theoretical and experimental advances in the field.

**Key Entities Extracted (13 triples):**

The analysis identified and mapped 13 major entities mentioned in the paper:

**Concepts (9):**
- Time crystal (the central topic)
- Time-translation symmetry
- Ergodicity
- Many-body problem
- Josephson effect
- Coupled map lattice
- Faraday wave
- Anderson localization
- Eigenstate thermalization hypothesis

**Tools/Platforms (3):**
- Quantum simulator
- Trapped-ion quantum computer
- Superconducting quantum computing

**Methods (1):**
- Quantum error correction

**Validation Status:** ✅ PASSED
- All Wikipedia URLs verified
- All required fields populated
- Paper has both "proposes" (Time crystal) and "uses" relations as required
- 13 triples with proper entity type classification
